ã€A little play with GraphRAGã€‘
GraphRAG seems to be structured in a way that allows for topic extraction during the entity generation process, so it looks like we can also generate structured text data for each topic. If we can output structured text data for each topic, humans can look at it and determine, "this is correct" or "this is wrong," so I plan to try to create structured text data within the next day or two.
It's not necessary to do this for this month's demo creation, but since this kind of thing can be useful later on, please let me do it a little.

```+------------------+        graphrag index        +---------------------------+
|  Raw Data (Document Group) |  ------------------------->  |  GraphRAG Indexer         |
|  PDFs, md, etc.  |                               |  (Extraction/Summarization/Community) |
+------------------+                               +------------+--------------+
                                                             |
                                                             |  Standard Output (Easy to Edit)
                                                             v
                                                 +-----------+-------------------------+
                                                 |  Output Table/JSON                 |
                                                 |  entities.parquet / relations...   |
                                                 |  communities.parquet               |
                                                 |  full_content_json/*.json          |
                                                 +-----------+-------------------------+
                                                             |
                                           (Manual Correction: Name Normalization/False Detection Removal/Hierarchy)
                                                             v
                                           +-----------------+------------------+
                                           | User Edited Structured Data         |
                                           | topics_fixed.json / csv            |
                                           +-----------------+------------------+
                                                             |
                             (Incremental Reflection: Import as a new period / use update_index_output)
                                                             v
+------------------+       graphrag index (incremental)     +---------------------------+
|  Existing Graph   | <------------------------------------- |  GraphRAG (Incremental Merge)       |
|  (Previous Output Group)   |                                       +---------------------------+
+------------------+                                                      |
                                                                          v
                                                           +--------------+-------------+
                                                           |  Search/Answer (local/global)  |
                                                           +----------------------------+```

It seems like we can create a cycle like this:
1. Show search results when the user needs it
2. Correct if it's wrong
3. Incrementally reflect the corrected structured data

> :jigsaw: First premise: Graphiti's update philosophy
> Graphiti has a principle of "not overwriting knowledge."
> All information is *appended* as a "new episode" and
> existing nodes and edges are simply *marked* as "expired" or "conflicted."
> In other words:
> :pencil2: Change = "Add a new claim that negates a past claim, with time information and source."

> Just before inserting a claim, Graphiti queries whether there exists a *valid (valid_to=null) relationship (Edge) with the same subject and predicate*.
> ```
> MATCH (s:Entity {uuid:$subject_id})-[r:$predicate]->(o)
> WHERE r.valid_to IS NULL
> RETURN r```
> â€¢ If there are no existing edges and it's a new claim, it will be added as is.
> â€¢ If there is an existing edge â†’ proceed to *conflict resolution logic*.
> 
> :brain: â‘¤ Conflict resolution policy
> Graphiti has two types of internal policies for resolving conflicts:
> Policy Processing Policy Example *invalidate (expiration mode)* sets the existing claim to `valid_to = now` and adds the new claim. The old knowledge remains as "past fact." Fact correction, value update, clear alternative (e.g., price change) *coexist (parallel retention mode)* retains the old claim and keeps the new claim as a separate version (confidence, provenance, time difference). Opinion conflict, uncertain information (e.g., two people gave different testimonies)

What is the Leiden method? I looked it up and it seems to be an improved method of graph clustering called the Louvain method.

The explanation of the Louvain method in this video was amazing.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xt0vBtBY2BU

In short, the Louvain method is a technique that greedily finds connections that maximize the connections within the same group compared to random graph connections.

The Leiden method solves the local optimization problem of the Louvain method by:
1. Checking for any disconnected parts within the clusters and ensuring they are internally connected (refinement).
2. Combining the refined clusters into a single node to create a new contracted graph.
    a. Creating a hierarchical structure graph.
3. Repeating this recursively.

1. TextUnit processing (segmentation)
â€¢ Split the input document into the minimum unit for analysis called "TextUnit." TextUnits are also used as sources for subsequent graph extraction.
2. Entity extraction (extraction of relationships and key claims)
â€¢ Extract entities and relationships between entities from TextUnits using LLM, constructing a knowledge graph (nodes = entities, edges = relationships). Key claims (output as "covariates (claim)" in GraphRAG) are also supported, which include information on who said what, when, where, and based on which evidence.
3. Community detection (hierarchical clustering with Leiden)
â€¢ Generate communities hierarchically using Leiden (or Louvain) on the constructed graph.
4. Summary generation (bottom-up)
â€¢ Create a "community summary (report)" for each community using LLM. The official workflow specifies bottom-up summarization that utilizes lower-level summaries to compile higher-level ones. The output includes a title, summary, main text, and key insights (findings).
